about.title: What is this?
about.body: This is a text message alert system to inform residents around KCBX Terminals that windspeed is high, and that they are therefore at increased risk of exposure to petroleum coke ("petcoke"). If you enter your phone number above, we will alert you when winds exceed 15 mph, the level deemed hazardous by the Chicago Department of Public Health. Longterm studies by Harvard University and the American Cancer Society have concluded that prolonged exposure to particulate matter such as petcoke increases the risk of heart disease and may increase the risk of lung cancer.

act.title: What can I do?
act.body-strong: Call the Mayor's office and demand ZERO THROUGHPUT for KCBX terminals.
act.body-main: Each text message will contain a link to a webpage containing a phone number and email address for the Mayor's office, as well as a script that you can read from to demand that KCBX stops polluting our homes and neighborhoods. We urge you to call EVERY TIME you receive a text, in order to create a public outcry that the Mayor can't ignore.

off-list.title: How can I unsubscribe?
off-list.body: To stop receiving SMS alerts, text "Unsubscribe" to 312-313-3200. You will receive a response text confirming that you have canceled your subscription.

define.title: What is petcoke?
define.body: Petcoke is a fine black carbon-based product of petroleum processing. When the wind is above 15 miles per hour, fine petcoke particles can become airborne, causing damage to your heart and lungs. KCBX Terminals maintains several large open-air stockpiles of petcoke on the far Southeast side of Chicago.

script.title: Here's a script if you're not sure what to say:
script.body: I'm calling to demand that the Department of Planning and Development recommend a petcoke throughput limit of ZERO for KCBX Terminals.  The American Cancer Society, Harvard University, and the EPA have determined that prolonged exposure to fine airborne dust particles, including petcoke, can lead to heart disease and lung disease, and this hazard must be eliminated from our community.
script.body-ps: Rahm Emanuel and John Pope said that they would "regulate petcoke out of Chicago". That strategy is failing. We need our elected officials to protect the people, not the polluters.

more-information.title: More information about Petcoke
more-information.intro-cont: a pamphlet released by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.  You can download the whole pamphlet
more-information.blockquote: ...The size of particles is directly linked to their potential for causing health problems. Small particles less than 10 micrometers in diameter pose the greatest problems, because they can get deep into your lungs, and some may even get into your bloodstream. Exposure to such particles can affect both your lungs and your heart...
more-information.blockquote-cont: such as those experienced by people living for many years in areas with high particle levels, have been associated with problems such as reduced lung function and the development of chronic bronchitis—and even premature death...
more-information.study-a: a long term study by Harvard University
more-information.study-b: followed particulate matter levels in six cities over 35 years. The study found that increased levels of fine particulate matter in the air was associated with increased risk of mortality, especially cardiovascular and lung cancer mortality. The paper concludes
more-information.study-strong: "...further public policy efforts that reduce fine particulate matter air pollution are likely to have continuing public health benefits."
